repnme.cdata!:
Tunisia - Energy Efficiency Program
            Industrial Sector Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Energy Efficiency
            Program Industrial Sector Project for Tunisia were as
            follows: outcomes were moderate satisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was substantial, the Bank performance
            was moderately unsatisfactory, and the Borrower performance
            was moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            grants and guarantees are not sufficient to develop an
            energy efficiency market, whereas capacity building
            (awareness, coordination, and training) is critical. The
            Tunisian experience showed that incentives were not
            immediately effective because there were serious obstacles
            to overcome: awareness about energy efficiency, low
            technical capacity, and lack of trust among key
            stakeholders. The role of a pro-active Project
            Implementation Unit (PIU) as a driver for market development
            was important at an early stage. This project provided two
            financial intermediation instruments, a subsidy and a
            guarantee, instead of one as in other similar operations. It
            allowed different stakeholders access to different support
            mechanisms, which led to a very complex administration
            model. The governance structure and eligibility criteria of
            both instruments were complex, which created more
            difficulties to the implementing agency managing the
            project. A simple structure should be sought in future
            projects to enhance development impacts. Commercial banks in
            Tunisia kept requesting large collaterals for ESCOs (Energy
            Service Company) credits despite the project's
            guarantee fund. While commercial banks were used to provide
            credit to regular industrial clients with adequate assets,
            ESCOs with small balance-sheets and
            'unconventional' energy efficiency projects were
            barred from credit. The cash-flow from energy savings is not
            a familiar form of revenue or collateral to back lending.
            The familiarization process by the banking sector on the
            evaluation of energy efficiency projects must not be
            underestimated. The project was well anchored in the
            government policy and the institutional structures. The
            decision to host the PIU at ANME (Agence Nationale pour la
            Maitrise de l'Energie - National Energy Management
            Agency) was highly positive. The ANME managed the newly
            created FNME, which provided the main incentive (20 percent
            subsidy) for energy efficiency projects. Hence, the 10
            percent subsidy provided by the PEEI (Programme Efficacite
            Energetique dans le secteur Industriel - Energy Efficiency
            Program in the Industrial Sector) project complemented it.
            The administrative coordination between the PIU and ANME to
            approve and disburse the subsidies was therefore easier.

repnme.cdata!:
Tunisia - Energy Efficiency Program
            Industrial Sector Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The main objective of the Energy
            Efficiency Program Industrial Sector Project is to overcome
            barriers to the development of a sustainable market for
            energy efficiency products. The closing date for the project
            was extended three times: a first extension from December
            31, 2009 to December 31, 2010 was granted in July 2009, a
            second extension to September 30, 2011 was granted in
            December 2010, and a third and final extension to November
            30, 2011 was granted in September 2011. A first reallocation
            of funds also took place in July 2010, totaling USD 625,000.
            USD 225,000 were reallocated to the guarantee component and
            USD 400,000 to the technical assistance, leading to the
            current budgets of USD 3.725 million and USD 2 million, respectively.

repnme.cdata!:
Tunisia - Energy Efficiency Program
            Industrial Sector Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The main objective of the Energy
            Efficiency Program Industrial Sector Project is to overcome
            barriers to the development of a sustainable market for
            energy efficiency products. In addition to the removal of
            institutional and capacity-related barriers, the project
            aims to establish energy services companies (ESCOs) as the
            main vehicle to guarantee a sustainable energy efficiency
            market. The closing date for the project will be extended
            from September 30, 2011 until November 30, 2011. This will
            be the third extension: the original closing date was
            December 31, 2009; a first extension to December 31, 2010
            was granted in July 2009; a second extension to September
            30, 2011 was granted in December 2010. The project's
            audit report for 2009 has been recognized by the World Bank
            as acceptable. A reallocation of funds also took place in
            July 2010, totaling USD 625,000. USD 225,000 were
            reallocated to the guarantee and USD 400,000 to the
            Technical Assistance (TA), leading to the current budgets of
            USD 3.725 million and USD 2 million, respectively.

repnme.cdata!:
Tunisia - Energy Efficiency Program
            Industrial Sector Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The main objective of the Energy
            Efficiency Program and Industrial Sector Project is to
            overcome barriers to the development of a sustainable market
            for energy efficiency products. The closing date for the
            project will be extended from December 31, 2010 until
            September 30, 2011. This will be the second extension. The
            original closing date was December 31, 2009, and a first one
            year extension was granted in July 2009. The Grant was
            approved on November 4, 2004, and became effective on
            December 13, 2004. Its amount is USD 8.5 million. As
            disbursement was very slow for the first years of
            implementation of the project, the Tunisian government
            requested an extension in May 2009. It was granted by the
            World Bank on July 23, 2009, while an action plan was being
            developed to accelerate disbursement. A reallocation of
            funds also took place in July 2010, totaling USD 625,000
            (USD 500,000 as per unallocated funds in the Grant
            Agreement, USD 125,000 from Sotugar fees, which were
            overestimated in the initial allocation). USD 225,000 were
            reallocated to the guarantee and USD 400,000 to the TA,
            leading to the current budgets of USD 3.725 million and USD
            2 million, respectively.
